The stock market opened decidedly lower Friday, as March's highly anticipated payroll report came up short in a couple of columns.The S&P 500 gave up 0.7% while the Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.6% each. Small caps outperformed, with the Russell 2000 up 0.3%.The stock market today heads into a busy session of economic releases, beginning with the March payrolls report.It showed job growth slowed, but not as much as expected in March, with the Labor Department reporting nonfarm employers added 215,000 workers vs. 245,000 hires in February. Economist consensus had projected 210,000 added workers. Private payroll additions came in below expectations at 195,000 vs. the 200,000 consensus.  The unemployment rate ticked higher, to 5% from 4.9% and above estimates for no change.Average hourly earnings rose a solid 0.3%, reversing a 0.1% slip in February and topping expectations for a 0.2% improvement.Researcher Markit releases its March manufacturing purchasing managers index at 9:45 a.m. ET.  At 10 a.m., the Institute for Supply Management's March manufacturing numbers, the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index and the Commerce Department's February construction spending data are all due out.Automakers will also be announcing March sales results throughout the session.Oil dropped more than 2%, putting West Texas Intermediate near $37 a barrel and down a bit more than 5%. It would be oil's first weekly slip since mid-February. Baker-Hughes (BHI) releases weekly rig count data at 1 p.m.Gold slipped a tad to just below $1,230 an ounce, but was up almost 1% and leaning toward its first gain after a three-week decline. The dollar was weaker, as were bonds, lifting the 10-year yield 2 basis points to 1.78%.The majority of Dow stocks moved lower, led by Chevron (CVX) and Caterpillar (CAT). McDonald's (MCD) bucked the trend early.On the Nasdaq 100, Tesla Motors (TSLA) jumped 6% after introducing its mass-market Tesla Model 3 sedan, which is 20% smaller than the Model S. It carried an initial price tag of $35,000 and comes with autopilot.The company reportedly booked 150,000 preorders for the cars, which won't be available until at least late 2017. Tesla shares have been hovering below a 239.98 buy point in a V-shaped cup-with-handle base. Premarket action implied an open well above that buy point. Premarket moves do not always carry through to regular trade.Marriott International (MAR) and Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) tumbled 5% each after an investor group led by China-based Anbang Insurance withdrew its increased counteroffer to buy Starwood. That leaves Starwood facing a vote from shareholders on whether to accept Marriott's $13.6 billion cash-stock pitch.Among IBD 50 stocks. Facebook (FB) outperformed early, rising 0.1%. Facebook is working on its seventh straight weekly advance, and ended Thursday 3% below a 117.69 buy point.Overseas, Europe's markets were under sharp pressure near midday and tracking toward a mixed finish to their holiday-shortened week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 crumbled 3.6% Friday after data showed a fall-off in confidence among large manufacturers. That left the index down 4.3% for the week. China's markets posted a mixed finished Friday, with Hong Kong's Hang Seng index ending the week up 0.8% and the Shanghai Composite ahead 1.6%.

The stock market ended Thursday with a whimper ahead of Friday's jobs report, but scored its biggest monthly gain since October.The Nasdaq closed fractionally higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each dipped 0.2%. All three major indexes wrapped up March with a 7% advance.Volume was lower across the board for the session vs. Wednesday, according to early figures. Winners narrowly outpaced losers with a 7-5 margin on the NYSE and by 9-7 on the Nasdaq.Biotech, generic drug stocks and automakers outperformed in the stock market today, while gold miners, travel bookers and car dealers lagged.After the close, Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) was down 4% and Marriott International (MAR) shed 5% amid reports that China's Anbang dropped its $14 billion takeover bid for Starwood.Medivation (MDVN) surged 23% in the regular session in healthy trade, retaking its 200-day moving average for the first time since mid-July. Shares spiked amid rumors that the San Francisco-based biotech hired bankers to fend off suitors.WebMD (WBMD) gapped up and soared 5% to its highest level in more than eight years. Shares are well extended past a 58.35 buy point initially cleared March 4. The online health care content provider will replace SunEdison (SUNE) in the S&P 400 midcap index after the close Friday.LendingTree (TREE) led the IBD 50 with a 6% pop. Volume was soft as the stock climbed past a 97.85 buy point of a cup with handle. Mizuho on Wednesday began covering the online lending service provider with a buy rating.Also on the IBD 50, BroadSoft (BSFT) rose nearly 5% in fast turnover, following through on a Tuesday breakout past a 39.20 handle buy point. It remains in buy range, 3% above the entry. The telecom software and service provider has stepped up profit and sales growth the past two quarters.All eyes will be on the March employment report, due Friday morning. Other economic data slated for release include the Purchasing Managers' Manufacturing Index, ISM manufacturing index and consumer sentiment, all for March, as well as construction spending for February.

Starwood Hotels (HOT) said Monday that it received a higher offer from the Waldorf Astoria's Chinese owners over the weekend, once again trumping  Marriott International (MAR).Starwood said the cash offer from the consortium, led by insurance major Anbang, came to $82.75 per share.Last November, Marriott and Starwood agreed to a merger worth $72.08 a share unless a "superior proposal” was offered by a competitor. After Anbang's group offered $78 on March 18, Marriott countered on March with $21 a share cash plus 0.8 share per Starwood share, initially worth $79.53 at the time.Under the new Anbang offer, Starwood stockholders would receive a portion of Interval Leisure Group (IILG) stock currently valued at $5.91 per Starwood share, bringing the total  Anbang deal to $88.66 per share, according to Starwood. (Marriott's offers also include Interval Leisure stock).Marriott responded to the Starwood announcement, reaffirming its commitment to buying its rival and saying it believes its amended merger deal is "the best course for both companies."Wells Fargo analyst Jeffrey Donnelly said Marriott may take its $450 million breakup fee and go home: "We suspect Marriott is done," he wrote in a client note. "We do not believe Marriott is willing to incur earnings dilution."Starwood shares climbed 2% to 83.75 in the stock market today. Marriott's stock rose 3.9% to 71.34. Interval Leisure retreated 0.4% to 13.87.Starwood's board continues to support the deal with Marriott -- for now -- but believes the Chinese offer likely will be a superior proposal.Marriott said in a statement: "Starwood stockholders should give serious consideration to the question of whether the Anbang-led consortium will be able to close the proposed transaction, with a particular focus on the certainty of the consortium's financing and the timing of any required regulatory approvals."

After getting a big boost from Donald Trump's surprise win, building materials provider NCI Building Systems (NCS) has just cleared a new buy point with earnings due after Thursday's market close. The president-elect's plan to spend heavily on infrastructure has had building sector stocks like Vulcan Materials (VMC), Martin Marietta Materials (MLM), U.S. Concrete (USCR) and NCI heading higher. Trump's…

One analyst poured cold water on expectations of a big premium for Twitter (TWTR) in a potential takeover. Disney (DIS) shares were downgraded, while a host of analysts updated their views of Marriott International (MAR) after its recent merger. Analysts supported Oshkosh (OSK) after the heavy truck manufacturer sold off on its earnings guidance.Oppenheimer downgraded the social media shares to underperform with a 17 target, after shares spiked on reports that Alphabet (GOOGL) property Google and Salesforce (CRM) were both in talks to buy the company.Analyst Jason Helfstein sees the likely buyer as a media company and doesn't expect an elevated valuation given slowing user growth and decreasing user engagement. He said he doesn't expect an Twitter buyer to pay "meaningfully more" than the 17 price target.Twitter shares reversed higher to close up 3.3% at 23.37 on the stock market today, on reports that Disney is weighing a possible bid for Twitter.Drexel Hamilton downgraded the media and entertainment conglomerate to hold from buy, cutting its price target to 102 from 112. The research firm lowered its subscriber targets, citing threats to the "traditional ecosystem" as video programming distributors integrate more content options.Meanwhile, Disney faces tough comparison to beat in its prior studio results and faces a 190% jump in its new NBA deal that's about to take effect.Disney shares slipped 1.4% to end at 91.96 Monday.Analysts think it's a better time to check into the hotel chain after completion of its $13 billion merger with Starwood last week. Morgan Stanley upgraded Marriott to overweight from equal weight, Goldman gave it a buy with an 81 target in new coverage, while Stifel kept a hold but bumped its target to 66 from 65.Marriott fell 1.9% to 67.15.IBD'S TAKE: Analyst ratings and price target changes sometimes move a stock or might be lagging indicators. It's worth considering what research firms have to say, but stock-chart analysis and an understanding of the market's trend give you the best chance to succeed. For a primer, visit IBD University and read IBD's Big Picture every day. JPMorgan Chase analysts upgraded Oshkosh to overweight from neutral, while Credit Suisse raised its rating to neutral with a 54 price target.Shares sank 10% on Friday after Oshkosh offered 2017 earnings guidance that was below analysts' estimates. On Monday, shares rose 3% to 52.42.

No. 3 online travel agency Expedia (EXPE) is partnering with Washington-based Red Lion Hotels (RLH), but larger chains like Hilton Worldwide (HLT) and Marriott International (MAR) are still guarding their discounted rates.Expedia stock rose 0.3% to close at 112.25 on the stock market today, a day after it announced Red Lion would extend its discounted rates to Expedia customers. Red Lion stock fell 0.45% to6.83.The deal requires Expedia customers to sign up for Red Lion's rewards program and agree to receive Red Lion marketing emails. Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman calls the move a departure from Expedia's typical practice of withholding customer emails.The arrangement "may be considered a major benefit by other hotels looking to boost loyalty program enrollment and direct email marketing lists," Kopelman wrote in a research report. "Expedia noted it is in 'deep discussions' with 'a lot of other chains' about member rates."But the Red Lion deal is technically a test and Expedia could decide to shutter the program. Red Lion is also a smaller chain and has typically supported online travel agencies (OTAs) as marketing partners.IBD'S TAKE: Expedia subsidiaries HomeAway and Trivago are each expected to reach $1 billion in sales next year. Meanwhile, Expedia says it's considering filing an initial public offering for Trivago.Larger chains like Hilton and Marriott have been steadily chipping away at discounts offered by Expedia, Priceline (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP) by offering steeper discounts to customers who book directly with the hotel. This allows the hotel to avoid paying OTA fees.Kopelman estimates about half of Expedia's business stems from the hotel chains, while TripAdvisor and Priceline are 40% and 15% exposed, respectively. He reiterated his outperform rating and 135 price target on Expedia stock, which is down 10% in 2016.In related news, TripAdvisor announced Thursday it had acquired New York-based Citymaps, a social mapping platform that helps tourists "uncover hidden gems and hot spots." The terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.TripAdvisor stock eased less than 0.1% to 61.90 Thursday. Priceline rose 0.4% to 1,415.64.RELATED:Priceline, TripAdvisor Jerked Ahead Of Earnings On Sabre's Mixed Q2Priceline, Expedia Call Truce On Google Battle; But Airbnb Clash Due

Hotel chains like Hilton Worldwide (HLT) and Marriott International (MAR) likely hurt No. 3 online travel agency Expedia (EXPE) during Q2, Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman said Tuesday. But Wall Street consensus expectations are for double-digit sales growth.At the close on the stock market today, Expedia shares shaved off 3 cents to 117.64. The shares are down 5% this year, while IBD's 10-company Leisure-Travel Booking industry group is up 2%. The group ranks a low No. 117 out of 197 groups tracked.IBD'S TAKE: None of the 10 companies in the Leisure-Travel Booking industry group is rated very highly. No. 1 online travel agency Priceline leads the group with an IBD Composite Rating of 87, meaning it performs in the top 15% of all stocks in key metrics. Get Priceline's Stock Checkup.In June, hotel chains upped their assault on Priceline (PCLN), Expedia and TripAdvisor (TRIP), offering "member rates" that undercut online travel agencies by 2%-20% in an effort to avoid 10%-15% online travel agency (OTA) fees, Kopelman said in a research report. He models 18% organic room-night growth vs. last year.That would decelerate from 24% growth in Q1, which enjoyed Easter Weekend and Leap Day tailwinds, Kopelman wrote.Priceline is the No. 1 OTA by market valuation, with China's Ctrip (CTRP) No. 2.For Q2, the consensus of 27 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters models Expedia to post $2.25 billion in sales, up 35% year over year, and 78 cents earnings per share ex items, down 12%. But analysts project a return to EPS growth in Q3.That's vastly too high, according to marketing analysis firm Jumpshot. Based on historical bookings trends and Jumpshot's tracking of 160 billion user clicks monthly, the firm predicts Expedia's Q2 sales coming in at $1.9 billion, up 26%.

Expedia (EXPE) subsidiaries HomeAway and Trivago will each reach $1 billion in sales next year, Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman predicted Friday after the online travel agency's mixed Q2 earnings report late Thursday.But that will follow share loss to No. 1 rival Priceline (PCLN) and hotel chains like Marriott International (MAR) and Hilton Worldwide (HLT), he said. Euromonitor analysts said this week that Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and TripAdvisor (TRIP) are pressuring online travel agencies.By the closing bell on the stock market today, Expedia stock fell 2.2% to 116.65. Shares are down 6% for the year, as IBD's 10-company Leisure Booking-Travel has risen 3%. On Friday, the travel stocks were up, with Priceline climbing nearly 2% to 1350.81. TripAdvisor lost 1.8% to 69.97.IBD'S TAKE: Priceline tops IBD's 10-company Leisure Booking-Travel industry group, but the group itself is only ranked No. 106 out of 197 groups tracked. Priceline stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 89, meaning it performs in the top 10% of stocks in terms of key metrics.For Q2, Expedia reported $2.1 billion in sales and 83 cents earnings per share ex items, up 32% and 7%, respectively, vs. last year. Sales missed analysts' view for $2.25 billion, but EPS beat the 78 cent expectation.Adjusted earnings before interest taxes depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) came in at $330.9 million, topping the consensus for $294.5 million, Credit Suisse analyst Stephen Ju wrote in a research report.HomeAway contributed $35 million to EBITDA, topping models by Kopelman and the consensus for $3 million and $17 million, respectively. HomeAway revenue accelerated 36% to $172 million on its new online booking commission fee model.But overall organic room night growth slowed to 12% year over year, from 24% in Q1. Kopelman noted headwinds including Orbitz's integration following its $1.3 billion acquisition last September, as well as share losses to Priceline and traditional hotels, and a weaker macroeconomy.Online travel has steadily improved since bottoming in 2009, Benchmark analyst Daniel Kurnos wrote in a report, but he says an uptick in terror attacks is likely to weight in the near term. Still, Expedia's international and domestic gross bookings increased a respective 16% and 31% in Q2.Expedia reiterated its full-year EBITDA model for 35%-45% growth. The company said the year will include greater contributions from HomeAway and Orbitz, which are already ahead of earlier guidance for $275 million to $325 million, Cowen's Kopelman said.That effectively lowered Expedia's core EBITDA expectations from 8%-13% growth, he wrote. And if room nights don't modestly accelerate in the second half of 2016, EBITDA will wrap the year close to the lower end of guidance.Kopelman lowered his 2016 EBITDA expectation to $1.635 billion, but he boosted his price target on Expedia stock to 135 from 130. He has an outperform rating on shares and in a research report highlighted bright spots like HomeAway's "blowout quarter" and a potential Trivago initial public offering.

The pleasant surprise of the First 100 Days is over. The action was hectic, heated, often confused, but well within the bounds of normalcy. Policy (e.g., health care) was being hashed out, a Supreme Court nominee confirmed, foreign policy challenges (e.g., North Korea) addressed.Donald Trump's character — volatile, impulsive, often self-destructive — had not changed since the campaign. But it seemed as if the guardrails of our democracy — Congress, the courts, the states, the media, the Cabinet — were keeping things within bounds.Then came the last 10 days. The country is now caught in the internal maelstrom that is the mind of Donald Trump. We are in the realm of the id. Chaos reigns. No guardrails can hold.Normal activity disappears. North Korea's launch of an alarming new missile and a problematic visit from the president of Turkey (locus of our most complicated and tortured allied relationship) barely evoke notice. Nothing can escape the black hole of a three-part presidential meltdown.Result? Layers of falsehoods giving the impression of an elaborate cover-up — in the absence of a crime. At least Nixon was trying to quash a third-rate burglary and associated felonies. Here we don't even have a body, let alone a smoking gun. Trump insists there's no there there, but acts as if the there is everywhere.The Israelis, whose asset might have been jeopardized, are no doubt upset, but the notion that this will cause a great rupture to their (and others') intelligence relationship with the U.S. is nonsense. These kinds of things happen all the time. When the Obama administration spilled secrets of the anti-Iranian Stuxnet virus or blew the cover of a double agent in Yemen, there was none of the garment-rending that followed Trump's disclosure.Once again, however, the cover-up far exceeded the crime. Trump had three top officials come out and declare the disclosure story false. The next morning, Trump tweeted he was entirely within his rights to reveal what he revealed, thereby verifying the truth of the story. His national security adviser H.R. McMaster floundered his way through a news conference, trying to reconcile his initial denial with Trump's subsequent contradiction. It was a sorry sight.Republicans are beginning to panic. One sign is the notion now circulating that, perhaps to fend off ultimate impeachment, Trump be dumped by way of 25th Amendment.That's the post-Kennedy assassination measure that provides for removing an incapacitated president on the decision of the vice president and a majority of the Cabinet.This is the worst idea since Leno at 10 p.m. It perverts the very intent of the amendment. It was meant for a stroke, not stupidity; for Alzheimer's, not narcissism. Otherwise, what it authorizes is a coup — willful overthrow by the leader's own closest associates.I thought we had progressed beyond the Tudors and the Stuarts. Moreover, this would be seen by millions as an establishment usurpation to get rid of a disruptive outsider. It would be the most destabilizing event in American political history — the gratuitous overthrow of an essential constant in American politics, namely the fixedness of the presidential term (save for high crimes and misdemeanors).Trump's behavior is deeply disturbing but hardly surprising. His mercurial nature is not the product of a post-inaugural adder sting at Mar-a-Lago. It's been there all along. And the American electorate chose him nonetheless.What to do? Strengthen the guardrails. Redouble oversight of this errant president. Follow the facts, especially the Comey memos. And let the chips fall where they may.But no tricks, constitutional or otherwise.RELATED:Democrats Want To Impeach A Republican President? What Else Is New?Trump's Whispering To Russians Isn't Fake News — But It Is A Fake IssueDemocrats Desperate To Turn Trump Into Nixon

XThree big buzz IPOs from Snap (SNAP), Alibaba (BABA) and Facebook (FB) all got off to a slow start, but premium apparel maker Canada Goose (GOOS) may be getting ready to soar. Facebook and Snap both quickly headed south following their initial public offerings. It took 14 months before Facebook's stock began to take off as Team Zuckerberg…

The major market averages held firm despite political furor over President Trump's abrupt firing of FBI Director James Comey, a Macy's (M)-led retail meltdown, bad news from Walt Disney and a Snap crash. On the upside, Nvidia (NVDA), OLED play Coherent (COHR) and new IPO Trade Desk (TTD) were big winners.The Nasdaq composite rose 0.3% for the week, hitting a new record high Wednesday as Apple (AAPL) and Netflix (NFLX) were among the big-cap techs setting all-time bests. The Dow industrials sank 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Higher oil prices lifted energy stocks, while bad news from Macy's, J.C. Penney (JCP) and several other retailers sent the broader sector tumbling. Snap fell close to its IPO price as Facebook (FB) competition takes its toll. But Nvidia skyrocketed to record highs on huge demand for its chips for graphics, artificial intelligence and more.Delivering its first earnings report since coming public, Snapchat-operator Snap missed on the top and bottom line. Snap said average revenue per user rose 181%, to 90 cents, but fell from $1.05 in the prior quarter. User growth was weaker than expected, with Facebook successfully cloning Snapchat's most popular features. Shares plunged more than 21% on Thursday to a post-IPO trading low, though they did rise 6% on Friday.3 top-rated IPOs also reported earnings. Digital ad platform Trade Desk (TTD) spiked Friday morning on better-than-expected earnings and revenue. Chip-equipment play Ichor (ICHR) reported results in line with bullish preliminary figures, but gave weak guidance. IT services firm Presidio (PSDO) fell after its results.RELATED:Snap Laughs Off Facebook Competition As Stock Plunges On Earnings MissGraphics chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) earnings rose 85% and sales surged 48% to $1.94 billion, beating views and helped by strong demand for processors for cloud computing data centers. Nvidia shares shot up 23% in the two days after the late Tuesday report. Microchip Technology (MCHP) and MaxLinear (MXL) also rallied on better-than-expected quarterly results.RELATED:Nvidia Surges 23% In Two Days On Earnings, GPU ConferenceWalt Disney (DIS) was forced to defend ESPN again as the premium sports cable network's subscriber losses accelerated slightly from the prior quarter; the timing of the call, not long after ESPN laid off about 100 mostly high-profile employees, put the channel back in the spotlight and CEO Bob Iger back in the hot seat. Results were mixed as revenue growth of 3% to $13.34 billion missed estimates and profit gains of 10% to $1.50 a share topped. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) turned in mixed results, topping on profit views, but cable ad revenue was weak. Ad revenue softness and subscriber declines have put media stocks under scrutiny lately.RELATED:21st Century Fox's Weak Cable Ad Revenue Follows Disney's ESPN WoesMacy's (M) led retailers after reporting weak quarterly results, as the department store operator is trying a variety of initiatives, hoping to find a solution to the long-time decline in brick-and-mortar retailer. Macy's sold off 17% on Thursday, then continued falling Friday, hitting its worst levels since 2011. Nordstrom (JWN) tumbled on disappointing same-store sales, while Kohl's (KSS) sold off mixed results. J.C. Penney (JCP) crashed to a record low Friday on its weak comps while Dillard's (DDS) also plunged. Many retailers are trying an array of things — from better e-commerce services to new beauty offerings to stores-within-stores — to prop up sales as more people buy things online or at discounters.RELATED:J.C. Penney Threatens All-Time Low On Weak Sales As Retail Woes ContinueMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkOPEC production fell in April thanks to decline in output from Libya, Iraq and Iran. But Saudi Arabia's production increased by nearly 50,000 barrels per day, according to OPEC's report. The increases come as OPEC and its allies debate extending the current production deal. On Tuesday, the International Energy Agency said an extension would reduce supply even further in the second half of the year. But U.S. shale is curbing the effectiveness of the cuts. On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration said U.S. stockpiles fell by 5.2 million barrels last week, a larger-than-expected drop. On Tuesday, the EIA raised its full-year U.S. oil production forecast for 2018 to 9.96 million barrels per day. U.S. crude futures rallied after tumbling 6.3% in the prior week.EOG Resources (EOG) said it could hit its targeted 18% production increase and operate with in cash flow if oil averages $47 per barrel. It plans to operate three more rigs than previously expected, but keep capital spending at $3.7 billion to $4.1 billion. EOG, sometimes called the "Apple (AAPL) of oil," touted its Big Data and proprietary mobile apps in helping cut costs while new wells in the Permian basin "shattered" industry records for early production. Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) raised its 2017 production outlook and Sanchez Energy (SN) said current Q2 production levels are already 46% higher than Q1 levels. Oasis Petroleum (OAS) said Q1 production soared 25.6%.Coherent (COHR) earned $2.91 a share, up 180%, in its fiscal Q2. Revenue rose 112% to $422.8 million. Shares skyrocketed to a new high. Coherent makes laser parts used in making OLED displays for TVs and increasingly smartphones. CEO John Ambroseo sees "unprecedented demand" across many of the company's verticals.E-commerce giant JD.com (JD), one of China's top performing internet companies, reported first-quarter results that topped estimates and guided second-quarter revenue above views, a week before rival Alibaba (BABA) reports. China online auto site Bitauto (BITA) reported first-quarter earnings that fell short of views, but a competing online auto website, Autohome (ATHM), topped expectations. China social networking company YY (YY) also beat the consensus estimate.Marriott (MAR) reported first-quarter earnings that topped estimates and gave a rosier outlook for revPAR — or revenue per available room — a reflection of postelection optimism. Several hotel operators have delivered strong earnings and big stock gains. Travel-information websites Priceline (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP), however, reported results that missed views.The video game publisher earned 85 cents a share excluding items, up 69% year over year, far above views, as sales grew 18% to $1.09 billion. Electronic Arts (EA) was helped by continued strong sales of its World War I shooter game "Battlefield 1" and growth in pro soccer game "FIFA 17." An industrywide shift to higher-margin digital game downloads boosted profit. EA shares soared to record highs.Online home furnishings retailer Wayfair (W) reported first-quarter results that topped analyst estimates and sent shares to all-time highs, putting the squeeze on short sellers in the process. A large amount of Wayfair shares are sold short, equivalent to almost 17 days' worth of trading.Target (TGT) is pilot-testing a next-day home-delivery service for "essentials" such as detergent and coffee in the Minneapolis area. The Target Restock service will be available to REDcard users for an unspecified flat fee as the big-box retailer seeks to catch up with Amazon (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT) moves in the delivery space. Amazon, for its part, cut its free-shipping minimum to $25 from $35, after trimming that from $49 earlier this year in reaction to Wal-Mart.M.D.C. Holdings (MDC) earned 43 cents a share, up 126% vs. a year earlier. Revenue swelled nearly 43% to $581.71 million vs. estimates of $509.9 million. LGI Homes (LGIH) earned 52 cents a share vs. 57 cents a year earlier. Revenue edged up 0.9% to $162.9 million. Shares of MDC rocketed 11% Tuesday to the highest in nearly four years. LGI Homes shot up 13.2%. Larger peers such as Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and KB Home (KBH) also rallied after the sector had turned spotty in recent weeks.Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) agreed to buy Tribune Media (TRCO) for $3.9 billion, or $43.50 a share, creating a TV station powerhouse after the FCC lifted ownership caps. Sinclair Broadcast, which will also assume $2.7 billion in debt, fell 5.55% for the week. Tribune Media, which had been rallying on buyout buzz, rose 2.7%.Coach (COH) will buy struggling handbag rival Kate Spade (KATE), to boost its appeal with younger women. Coach will pay $2.4 billion, or $18.50 a share, less than some had speculated.Yelp (YELP) crashed 18.4% Wednesday after the local search-and-reviews site reported weak revenue and gave guidance that was far below analyst estimates.

On Wednesday, Vertex Pharma (VRTX) got an upgrade for its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating from 94 to 96.The upgrade means the stock is now outpacing 96% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength.Vertex Pharma is not currently near a proper buy zone. See if the stock goes on to form a new base and offer a new buying opportunity.The stock rocketed over 20% higher on Mar. 28 on results for its cystic fibrosis drug.One weak spot is the company's 79 EPS Rating, which tracks quarterly and annual earnings growth. Look for that to improve to 80 or better to show it's in the top 20% of all stocks.Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B shows moderate buying by institutional investors over the last 13 weeks.The company reported a 356% earnings gain for Q1. Vertex has now posted triple-digital EPS gains in five of the last six quarters, and just barely missed in Q4 with a 94% rise.Top line growth increased 80% in Q1, up from 10% in the prior report. That marks one quarter of rising revenue increases.Vertex Pharma earns the No. 2 rank among its peers in the Medical-Biomed/Biotech industry group. Supernus Pharmaceuticals (SUPN) is the top-ranked stock within the group.RELATED:Which Companies Are Now Outperforming 95% Of All Stocks?Vertex Rockets To 14-Month High On Cystic Fibrosis Drug Results

The S&P 500 fell 0.2% and continued to meet resistance at the 2400 level, though it made a new intraday high. The Dow Jones industrial average is tracing…

Forecasts for an improving economy and low gas prices should result in a busy summer for the U.S. tourism industry and a bullish outlook for companies that make money on free-spending vacationers.One of the likely beneficiaries is Marriott Vacations Worldwide (VAC). It develops, markets, sells and manages vacation ownership and related products — aka timeshares — under the Marriott Vacation Club, Grand Residences by Marriott and Ritz-Carlton Destination Club brands.Although Marriott Vacations Worldwide isn't as tied to macro factors as other travel-related stocks such as airlines, hotel operators and cruise lines, it still gets a lift when times are good."The numbers in terms of people driving, as well as the forecasts for air travel, are back to pre-2008-09 levels. That bodes well for us," Chief Financial Officer John Geller told IBD. "Going into the summer, we are optimistic and the trends are good."Reflecting that optimism, Marriott Vacations Worldwide stock hit a record high of 89.85 on May 28 and is up about 18% this year.It is one of a number of stocks in IBD's Leisure-Services group to hit new highs in recent weeks. The group ranks No. 35 of 197 industries tracked and has moved steadily higher over the past six months.Other leaders in the group are a diverse mix that includes cruise operator Norwegian Cruise Line (NCLH), sports and entertainment company Madison Square Garden (MSG) and fellow timeshare company Interval Leisure Group (IILG).The Price Of ParadiseMarriott Vacations, which was spun off from Marriott International (MAR) in November 2011, has 59 resorts worldwide. In coming quarters, it will open new resorts in San Diego, Miami Beach and Hawaii.The company competes with the vacation ownership divisions of hotel rivals such as Hilton Worldwide Holdings (HLT), Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT), Wyndham Worldwide (WYN) and Hyatt Hotels (H).Marriott Vacations Worldwide plays in the high end of the market. The company's average first-time buyer spends $30,000 to $35,000 for the ability to stay a week each year — perpetually — at a two-bedroom, two-bath vacation home in locations such as Orlando, Fla., and Hilton Head, S.C.That compares with an average sales price of about $20,000 industrywide, according to data from the American Resort Development Association (ARDA), a timeshare trade association.It sounds like a lot of money until you start doing the math, says ARDA CEO Howard Nusbaum."It's not like real estate in the sense that you don't make money flipping it," he told IBD. "Your value comes from your use of the property. If you spend $3,000 a year for vacations, in 10 years you spent $30,000."With a timeshare, you might spend that much and get a lifetime's worth of vacations, Nusbaum says.About half of Marriott Vacation Worldwide's revenue comes from contract sales to customers. It gets about 20% from resort management and other income, including what comes from some ancillary businesses like food and beverage, spas and golf courses, in addition to management fees.Another 20% comes from renting out unsold units. The remaining 10% comes from providing financing to customers, most of whom can't get timeshare loans from traditional lenders.For most of its three-plus years as a standalone company, Marriott Vacation Worldwide's revenue growth has hovered in the single digits. That's primarily because it spent its early years focusing on operating efficiently rather than growing rapidly."Coming out of the spin-off, our focus was really about improving margins and looking at how to operate as a standalone company," CFO Geller said. "We were less concerned about driving top-line growth."From Crisis To CruisingMeanwhile, the timeshare industry itself was still emerging from the beating that it took in 2008-09, when the recession and financial crisis made it all but impossible for many Americans to get timeshare loans.Normally, the industry isn't that vulnerable to economic swings. That's because travelers who own timeshares don't have to worry about coming up with money for a place to stay. But the downturn of 2008-09 was different because "the financing dried up overnight," Nusbaum said. Industry revenue fell by nearly half."Timeshare companies couldn't get loans, so they couldn't offer loans to customers," he said. "We had 20 years of double-digit growth, but the 2008-09 downturn was very humbling."With those problems behind the industry, it is now back to double-digit growth, he says.As for Marriott Vacations Worldwide, it has moved into a new phase where it can put more focus on top-line growth. During the first quarter, it posted a 13% year-over-year revenue increase — its biggest gain since going public."In the first quarter, we started to ramp up our marketing efforts," Geller said. "We shifted our focus more to first-time buyers."First-time buyers account for only about 40% of the company's contract sales, he says. The rest comes from sales to existing owners looking to upgrade or add to their portfolios."We want to get that to more of a 50/50 ratio," Geller said.In the first quarter, Marriott Vacations Worldwide posted total revenue of $454.9 million, up from $401.9 million a year earlier. Total company contract sales climbed 23% to $198.4 million, while earnings rose 52% to 85 cents a share, as calculated on a diluted basis, topping the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Renting 'Experiences' Pays OffMarriott Vacations Worldwide describes its points system, which members use to choose resorts and "pay" for stays, as a "flexible 'vacation currency.'"And the company has added not only resorts but also things like cruises, guided tours and "experiences" that range from ski trips to golf excursions."As we have been able to put our Destination Club in place — and it's really gotten a lot of traction — keep in mind that when our owners decide that they want to use their Vacation Club points for something other than staying in one of our resorts, whether they want to take a cruise or they want to take a tour or go to the Masters or whatever, they give us back those points for the year," CEO Steve Weisz said on the company's Q1 conference call in May. "We turn around and take them into the open market, and we rent them. So that drives the revenue side of things."If it all works right," Weisz said, "we actually make a little bit in the arbitrage between what we rent it for and what we have to pay for the cost to fulfill the particular thing that they asked for, whether it be the cruise or the trip."Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company's full-year EPS to rise 19% in 2015 and another 16% in 2016."As the economy improves and wealth improves, demand for people going on vacation increases both in terms of the duration of their breaks, the number of breaks, and how much they're spending on different amenities like timeshares," MKM Partners analyst Christopher Agnew told IBD. "That should be good for the industry."

Since Blackstone's stake would fall below 50%, Hilton would no longer be "a controlled entity," said analyst Robin Farley of UBS in…

China search leader Baidu (BIDU) has begun the rollout of indoor location services powered by indoor mapping provider IndoorAtlas to the 270 million monthly active users of its Baidu Maps service. Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide, the owner of brands including the W and St. Regis, rose the most in five years Wednesday after saying it plans to explore strategic alternatives, opening the door to a company sale. It gave back some of the gain Thursday. "No option is off the table, and we will take the time we need to…

Stocks kicked off the week with a quiet performance Monday, holding small gains in early afternoon trading.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each rose 0.2%. The Nasdaq added 0.1%. Volume on both exchanges was tracking below Thursday's pre-holiday levels. Advancing stocks had a slight edge over decliners on the NYSE, while it was the opposite situation on the Nasdaq.In economic news, new data from the Commerce Department showed that income gains continued to decelerate in February. Meanwhile, GDP data Friday showed that the economy grew at a faster rate in Q4 than initially reported.In the stock market today, Starwood (HOT) picked up 2% after China-based Anbang trumped a revised offer from Marriott (MAR) to acquire Starwood. Shares of Marriott jumped 4%.Other gainers included Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA). The company's class A shares added 0.8% to 212,300 after UBS initiated coverage of the Warren Buffett-led company with a buy rating and set a 244,500 price target.In the retail space, Dollar General (DG) outperformed, rising more than 2%. It completed a three-weeks-tight pattern last week, a bullish structure to watch for a breakout.Inside the IBD 50, MaxLinear (MXL) recovered nicely after a volatile session Thursday, with its shares rising 3%. The stock on Thursday erased a double-digit gain from a 16.29 double-bottom buy point. A 17.85 buy point, however, is still in play.In the building sector, volume stayed light in Fortune Brands Home & Security (FBHS) as shares rose 0.6%. It's near the high end of a buy range from a 52.70 cup-with-handle buy point. Earnings and sales growth has accelerated for three straight quarters.On the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for May delivery lost nearly 1% to $39.11 a barrel. The 10-year Treasury yield eased 3 basis points to 1.87%.

If there's one thing Rick Simonson wants to make clear, it's that Sabre (SABR) is not a travel company."Our customers are travel companies," Sabre's chief financial officer said in an interview with IBD. "We're the technology provider to the travel industry."Even so, Texas-based Sabre has been doing a lot of traveling lately -- to the cloud. Sabre's business in software-as-a-service (SaaS) and its work with airlines, hotels and other travel-oriented businesses is growing faster than the firm's mainstay travel network segment, which consists largely of its global distribution system.That system provides reams of information, such as prices and inventory -- most notably on airlines -- to travel agents, online agencies like Expedia (EXPE) and other travel buyers. Hotels are a smaller but growing portion of that, thanks in part to a deal struck last year with Wyndham Worldwide (WYN), its first large-scale hotel partner."The (global distribution system) is a more mature market," Morningstar analyst Dan Wasiolek told IBD, adding that it accounts for about 70% of Sabre's revenue.The other 30% of Sabre's revenue comes from its software platform, which it calls Airline and Hospitality Solutions. It provides reservation, inventory management and other software services to airlines and hotels. It's in its early stages but serves as a key growth engine, Wasiolek says.Whether old or new, however, Sabre's back-end technology essentially touches almost every step of a traveler's journey, from looking into and booking travel to boarding and checking in, whether with an airline or hotel. And on the operations side, its software helps airlines manage crews and tasks such as monitoring fuel levels, cargo weight and routing. For hotels, its software can manage bookings and come up with optimal room prices based on demand and other factors.Sabre expects its tech solutions business to top $1 billion in revenue this year, up more than 17% over last year. That compares with 5% to 6% growth expected in its core so-called travel network business, excluding revenue from last year's acquisition of Singapore-based Abacus International, a business-to-business e-commerce travel company focused on the Asia-Pacific market.Sabre bought the remaining 65% interest in Abacus it didn't already own. With Abacus included, management thinks travel-network revenue will grow 13.5% to 14.5% this year."We will approach $3.5 billion in (total) revenue, which makes us one of the bigger software companies in the world," Simonson said, adding that margins and cash flow also are increasing. Revenue in 2015 rose 12.5% to $2.96 billion.After growing 17% in 2015, per-share earnings are seen increasing by 32% this year to $1.45 a share, according to a poll of analysts by Thomson Reuters.  Earnings are expected to grow 18% next year."Sabre continues to evolve from a slower-growing travel distribution business to a technology-driven SaaS company, providing cloud-based solutions to travel suppliers," wrote analyst Mark Moerdler of Bernstein in a client note. He sees Sabre's SaaS business growing in the mid teens vs. single-digit growth for its global distribution system.Sabre is best known for its global distribution system, one of the two largest in the world along with chief rival Amadeus, based in Spain and big in Europe. A third, smaller player is U.K.-based Travelport Worldwide (TVPT). Many airlines use more than one global distribution system, and it's usually Amadeus and Sabre, and to a lesser extent Travelport.Airlines pay Sabre a modest flat fee for every air ticket booked, so traffic counts more than price. A portion of the fee is paid to a travel agency as an incentive for using its global distribution system."The net fee we keep is our gross profit," Simonson said.Sabre is riding a growing air passenger market. Global air traffic grew 7.8% in the first two months of 2016 from a year earlier, according to the International Air Transport Association, or IATA. It was the strongest start to a year since 2008, IATA said.Simonson says that Sabre has more than 400 airline clients, covering most of the globe. Some of its newest airline customers include Italy's Alitalia, Air Berlin, Panama-based Copa Holdings (CPA) and Brazil's TAM Airlines (owned by LATAM Airlines (LFL)).Last year, Sabre completed what it says was the largest airline reservations system integration and upgrade in the airline industry, for client American Airlines (AAL), following its merger with U.S. Airways. The chief executive of American said the work was "flawless," Simonson said.On the software solutions side of the business, Sabre gets a set fee for providing software and data for handling functions involved in getting passengers on board a plane. It also gets a fee for every person "boarded" in a hotel room, plus additional fees for providing other operational hotel services, such as digital marketing and property management.In Wyndham, Sabre landed what Simonson described as the "largest hotelier in the world" as a partner. The win last year was "huge," he said. Sabre is currently rolling out a central reservation system across 7,600 Wyndham properties worldwide.Earlier, Sabre announced it would handle central reservations for the privately held Four Seasons Hotels.Most hotels, including big chains such as Hilton (HLT) and Marriott (MAR), still handle such work in-house. Sabre's hotel business had previously focused on smaller, independent hotels around the world.The company's hospitality solutions business serves around 32,000 hotel properties, including hotels gained from its acquisition in January of Trust Group, a central reservation, revenue management and hotel marketing firm with a presence in Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia-Pacific.But it's the Wyndham win that's especially key to landing other large-scale hotels that may be inclined to follow suit and also outsource work to third-party experts such as Sabre, Simonson says.Analysts agree."The (hospitality solutions) business has significant runway, and we expect the accelerated pace to sustain with Wyndham as an anchor client," wrote Ashish Sabadra in a recent report for Deutsche Bank Securities.

Stocks scratched out thin gains early Monday, with some help from a passel of decent economic news and a bump up in oil prices.Dow stocks pulled up 0.2%, while the S&P 500 inched up 0.1%, and the Nasdaq made a fractional gain.Volume swept lower, down more than 20% on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE, compared with levels Thursday morning, when stocks last traded.The stock market today opened to generally healthy economic news, with Q4 GDP data reported when markets were closed Friday coming in better than expected, at a growth rate of 1.4%.The Labor Department reported early Monday that personal income rose 0.2% in February, down sharply from January's 0.5% gain but better than the 0.1% increase expected by economists' consensus. Spending inched up 0.1%, equal to January's downwardly revised number and in line with expectations. Price growth was steady, up 0.1%, although core prices -- minus energy and food -- slowed to a 0.1% increase, vs. 0.3% in January. Consensus projected a steeper 0.2% rise.Real estate sales were a positive, with pending home sales jumping 3.5% in February, according to the National Association of Realtors. The group also revised its estimate for January lower, to a 3% decline. Economists had expected a 1.5% gain in February.Dow stocks were evenly divided and holding to gains and losses of less than 1% each.Marriott International (MAR) skipped up 4% to the head of the S&P 500. The bidding war between Marriott and China's Angbang Insurance to acquire Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) amped up Monday. The consortium led by Angbang raised its latest bid to what Starwood estimated Saturday would total a combined current value of $88.66 per share. Starwood shares rose nearly 3% in early trade.Finish Line (FINL) broadjumped 9% after Jefferies raised the stock's price target to 24 from 22, while also maintaining the stock's buy rating.Noble Energy (NBL) dropped 7% in opening trade. Israel's supreme court ruled Sunday against allowing an offshore gas development deal by a joint venture between Noble and Israel-based Delek Group. Israeli regulators had ruled the project illegal in 2014, saying it constituted a monopoly.Video game retailer GameStop (GME) tumbled 4% in early action, though the shares later trimmed their loss to sit just a fraction lower. The Grapevine, Texas, firm gave Q1 EPS guidance well below consensus expectations.Among IBD 50 stocks, handgun manufacturers Smith & Wesson (SWHC) and Sturm Ruger (RGR) rose 4% and 2%, respectively, in heavy trade. Both stocks fell hard Thursday, possibly due to cautious comments tied to a Q4 results report from Sportsman's Warehouse (SPWH). Monday's gain lifted Smith & Wesson back above a 26.64 buy point after tripping a sell signal Thursday.

Hotel chains such as Hilton Worldwide (HLT) and Marriott International (MAR) are chipping away at discounts offered by online travel agencies (OTAs) Priceline (PCLN), Expedia (EXPE) and TripAdvisor (TRIP), Cowen analyst Kevin Kopelman said Tuesday.No. 1 OTA Priceline is least exposed, with only 10%-15% of its business stemming from the U.S., where the online donnybrook is mushrooming. Half of TripAdvisor's and 52% of Expedia's sales are tied to the U.S., he said."These (hotel chain direct) discounts are in addition to loyalty program points and other offers/benefits being provided to customers only when they book direct with the hotel," Kopelman wrote in a research report.Direct discounts range between 2% and 20% cheaper than booking with OTAs, Kopelman wrote. He estimates 50% and 40% of Expedia and TripAdviser's sales are exposed to hotel chains. Only about 15% of Priceline is exposed.Importantly, he said, the direct-booking trend threatens to undo the reputations of OTAs like Priceline and Expedia which offer "Best Price Guarantees" that don't appear to cover the new "member rates" by hotel chains."If the chains are successful in getting the message out that their own sites carry cheaper rates, they may be able to train customers to check the hotel website first before booking, decreasing OTA conversion rates," he wrote.But consumers largely aren't loyal to specific hotel chains, and most hotel chains have yet to buy in on the direct-booking game, Kopelman wrote. Plus, Expedia has a series of popular loyalty programs.On the stock market today, Priceline erased small losses to close up 0.6% at 1275.03. Expedia stock closed down 1.65% to 105.93. TripAdvisor stock dipped 0.5% to 64.30.Hilton shares lost 2.2% while Marriott fell 1%.

China's Anbang Insurance Group late Thursday ended its bid for Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide (HOT), leaving Marriott International (MAR) as the likely winner of the long-running bidding war for Starwood."We were attracted to the opportunity presented by Starwood because of its high-quality, leading global hotel brands, which met many of our acquisition criteria, including the ability to generate consistent, long-term returns over time, Anbang-led consortium said in a statement. "However, due to various market considerations, the Consortium has determined not to proceed further. We thank the Starwood Board, management team and its advisors for their efforts and support throughout this process."The Wall Street Journal initially reported Anbang's exit, quickly followed by other publications before the Chinese firm's confirmation.Starwood, which owns Sheraton, Westin and St. Regis hotel chains fell sharply in extended trading. So did Marriott.Starwood originally agreed to a $12.2 billion offer from Marriott in November. Anbang countered with an offer. On March 21, Marriott made a revised offer of $13.6 billion, consisting of $10 billion of Marriott stock and $3.6 billion cash.On Monday, Starwood's board issued a statement saying a revised proposal from a consortium consisting of Anbang, J.C. Flowers and Primavera Capital was reasonably likely to lead to a "superior proposal," but noted that it had not officially dropped its support for the Marriott offer.Marriott on Monday reaffirmed its desire to acquire Starwood, saying in a statement that it was "confident that the previously announced amended merger agreement is the best course for both companies."Starwood stock has been consolidating for nearly eight months amid uneven earnings growth and nine straight quarters of shrinking revenue on a year-over-year basis. Its shares fell 4% in extended hours trading after closing down 0.3% in the stock market today.Marriott has been forming a cup-with-handle base with a 73.99 buy point. However, its stock fell 5% in late trading after closing down 0.5% at 71.18.

Stocks staged a big upward reversal to close out the first trading day of April on a positive note, amid a flurry of mostly positive economic reports.The Nasdaq led with a 0.9% gain, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each added 0.6%. Volume rose on both major exchanges vs. Thursday, according to early figures. Losers outpaced winners by a small margin on the NYSE, but advancers beat decliners by nearly 3-to-2 on the Nasdaq. For the week, the Nasdaq rose 3%; the Dow and S&P 500 climbed close to 2% each.In Friday's economic news, U.S. payrolls increased by 215,000 workers in March, slightly above expectations, despite a slight uptick in the jobless rate to 5%. Consumer confidence in March also edged past forecasts to 91, up from 90 in February. The ISM manufacturing index rose to 51.8 in March from 49.5 in February, its first foray above the neutral 50 level since August. Economists expected 50.5.West Texas intermediate crude prices slid 4% to below $37 a barrel.The top gainers in today's stock market action included biotechs, carmakers and other drug stocks.Tesla Motors (TSLA) surged as much as 8% intraday before settling for a 3% gain in fast turnover. Orders for the electric car maker's Model 3 mass-market sedan, which was unveiled Thursday evening and starts at $35,000, are pouring in. CEO Elon Musk confirmed at least 198,000 orders. The stock, up nearly 70% from its Feb. 9 low, is now 17% below its 52-week high.Among biotechs, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) soared 12% in robust trade, regaining its 50-day line for the first time since late December. Shares are still well below their 200-day line and 32% off their 52-week high. The biotech and partner Sanofi (SNY) said their dupilumab atopic dermatitis drug met key goals in two late-stage trials. They plan to file for FDA approval in Q3. Sanofi gained 1% in above-average volume.Inside the IBD 50, Smith & Wesson (SWHC), Sturm Ruger (RGR) and Six Flags Entertainment (SIX) each rose more than 4% in turnover higher than usual. Six Flags was featured in Friday's Stock Spotlight column.Energy, hotel and car dealers lagged.Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) fell 5% and Marriott International (MAR) gave up 6% after an investor group led by China's Anbang Insurance withdrew its offer to buy Starwood. Marriott's most recent offer for the hotel chain was $13.6 billion.Economic data coming up Monday include February personal income and outlays, the pending home sales index for February and the Dallas Fed manufacturing survey for March.

The major averages remained higher in late afternoon trading Friday, led by blue chip stocks. Volume was running well above Thursday's levels.The Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq each climbed 0.3%. Turnover jumped more than 60% on the NYSE and was nearly 20% higher on the Nasdaq compared to Thursday. Friday is an expirations day, which often boosts volume.Medical, leisure and transportation stocks fared best, while oil stocks fell as crude prices slipped due to a rise in U.S. oil rig counts.Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), a maker of robotic surgical systems, jumped more than 3% and retook a 580.10 buy point. However, volume was running only about 22% above average, a bit lower than desirable.Meanwhile, Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) popped 5% in heavy volume after spurning an offer by Marriott International (MAR) to buy the hotel operator. Instead, Starwood said it would consider a higher offer from a group of investors led by China's Anbang Insurance. Marriott rose 2%.Most IBD 50 stocks were higher as growth stocks finally appeared to gain some traction in a market dominated recently by defensive stocks such as utilities.Chip designer Nvidia (NVDA) rose more than 3%, clearing a 33.16 buy point of a cup-with-handle base after Argus initiated coverage with a buy rating. Nvidia, a supplier to Apple (AAPL) and Tesla (TSLA), is a leader in graphic-processing chips used in personal computers, game consoles and mobile devices. It's also moving into the emerging virtual reality market.

Stocks slipped into the red early Tuesday as oil prices reversed lower. The Nasdaq composite hit a new record high despite another solid gain from Apple (AAPL).The S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite each fell 0.1%; the Dow Jones industrial average held a fractional loss. The small cap Russell 2000 lagged, down 0.4%. Volume was lower across the board in the stock market today vs. the same time Monday.Gold miners, hotel operators and telecom-related plays were among top gainers in early trade, while department stores, solar and airline stocks underperformed.Apple led the upside on the Dow with a near 1% gain to a new all-time high in rapid turnover. Shares are now in profit-taking range, more than 20% past a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point. Apple launched several new products Tuesday including a red iPhone 7, lower-cost iPad and a short video-making app called Clips.Nike (NKE) reversed slightly lower ahead of its earnings report due after the close. Analysts expect the athletic shoe giant to report a 4% slip to 53 cents per share on 5% higher sales to $8.47 billion. That would mark its first year-over-year EPS decline since late 2012.Among other blue chips, drugmakers Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE) (PFE) were up about 0.5% each, but Goldman Sachs (GS) and Caterpillar (CAT) were down more than 0.5% apiece.Marriott International (MAR) gapped up and rose 2%, striking a new intraday high in big volume. The hotel operator announced three-year growth plans that include earnings of $5.25 to $5.80 a share and a 17% to 21% compound growth rate. Shares are near the top of a buy range from an 86.25 flat-base entry.Non-U.S.-based stocks led the IBD 50: France's Criteo (CRTO), and China's TAL Education (TAL) and Weibo (WB) scored gains north of 2% each.On the downside, Lennar (LEN) fell more than 1% in heavy trade after reporting fiscal Q1 earnings that declined year over year, but topped views. That snapped a multiyear streak of quarterly increases. Shares remain extended past a 47.69 cup-with-handle entry.RELATED:Dow's Nike Expected To Log First Earnings Decline In Over 4 Years Apple Debuts Red iPhone 7, Cheaper iPad, New Video App

Syria: President Trump sent a loud message to Syria's Bashar al-Assad for his use of deadly Sarin gas against his own people: Your days of terrorizing your own people with chemical weapons are about to end. But many others are getting Trump's message, too."Tonight, I ordered a targeted military strike on the air base in Syria from where the chemical attack was launched," Trump said, speaking from Mar-a-Lago in Florida. "It is in this vital national security interest of the United States to prevent and deter the spread and use of deadly chemical weapons."Two U.S. ships in the Mediterranean launched 59 Tomahawk missiles, striking Shayrat Airfield in western Syria, which U.S. intelligence believes has been used as a base for deadly chemical attacks against Assad's own people — including the 100 murdered this week in a Sarin gas attack."Using a deadly nerve agent, Assad choked off the lives of men, women and children," Trump said Thursday, visibly moved, adding: "No child of God should ever suffer such a horror."So it's official: "Leading from behind," as official U.S. foreign policy, is dead. "Leading" is back.Trump has clearly signaled that, after 8 years, the U.S. is ready to re-engage in the Mideast and elsewhere. This has been clear in recent weeks, as he's pointedly met with a handful of moderate and U.S.-friendly leaders in the Mideast to build a new coalition of sorts and to reassert U.S. leadership in the region.Just this week, he met with Egypt's Egypt's President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and with Jordan's King Abdullah II, and he's recently talked with the Saudis and with Israel's Benjamin Netanyahu. He engaged Germany's Angela Merkel, Britain's Theresa May and Japan's Shinzo Abe. It's clear Trump's intent on re-establishing the damaged ties from President Obama's tenure.But equally clear, the strike by 59 Tomahawk missiles against the Syrian military base from which chemical weapon attacks were likely launched, was a broader message from Trump to other recipients:It's not our job to wargame what comes next, or play armchair general. We're not beating a drum for war, or for U.S. troops to be sent back to the Mideast.But Assad crossed a red line, one that poses a danger to all of civilization. The last time he did that, we did nothing. Now, a new president is showing Assad — and the rest of the world — that such murderous acts will have very serious consequences.And that's a very good thing for America and the world.RELATED: Can Trump Clean Up Obama's Mess In Syria?Cold War 2.0: Obama Doctrine Of Weakness Has Reawakened The Russian Bear Kerry's Syrian 'Cease-Fire' Is Really Just Capitulation

The Nasdaq composite opened at a record high, with Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN) and Netflix (NFLX) all hitting all-time bests, but gains quickly withered.The Nasdaq jumped more than 0.4% early, but has reversed to fall 0.1% in the stock market today, The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index also turned down 0.1%.Several big names reported earnings this morning, led by Lennar (LEN) and General Mills (GIS). But the big-cap earnings fireworks occur after the close, when FedEx (FDX) and Dow component Nike (NKE) are due to report. FedEx rose fractionally and Nike dipped. Nike shares are in buy range from a 58.52 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Marriott International (MAR) rose 1.7%. Marriott jumped after announcing a 3-year growth strategy, targeting earnings of $5.25 to $5.80 a share and a compound growth rate of 17% to 21% by 2019. Shares are extended from a buy point of 86.25.Homebuilder Lennar fell nearly 3% after turning in fiscal first-quarter results that were above forecasts. Earnings declined, breaking a string of increases at least 20 quarters long. Revenue rose 17%, and home deliveries, average prices and new orders all increased. The stock is extended above a cup-with-handle buy point of 47.69.Metals mining stocks were mixed, but Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) flashed a 2% gain after Deutsche Bank upgraded the stock to hold from sell, and raised its price target to 14 from 12.40. Freeport has been trading tightly along its 40-week moving average, attempting to fashion a bottom in a seven-week consolidation. A Jan. 24 breakout failed.General Mills edged higher as fiscal third-quarter earnings narrowly topped expectations, but revenue slipped more than projected. The company's earnings guidance was above consensus targets. Shares have been consolidating since July.El Pollo Loco (LOCO) edged lower after posting a fourth straight quarter of flat or lower earnings. Revenue narrowly beat estimates, but management's full-year earnings guidance was below analysts' views.Oil prices inched higher, but West Texas Intermediate stayed well within its recent trading range between $48 and $49 a barrel. Gold traded flat near $1,233 an once. The dollar shifted lower vs. both the euro and the yen. The 10-year Treasury yield rose 2 basis points to 2.48%.Speaking in London this morning, New York Federal Reserve Bank President William Dudley argued banks need more carefully designed incentives, and said the scandal in which Wells Fargo (WFC) opened more than 2 million accounts without customer permission occurred largely because management failed to match employee incentives to the company's ethics policy.Kansas City Fed President Esther George and Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren are both scheduled to speak after the market closes this evening.Markets in Europe remained mixed in afternoon trade, with the FTSE 100 in London down 0.2%, Frankfurt's DAX up 0.2% and the CAC 40 in Paris holding a 0.5% gain.Markets across Asia posted an active session Tuesday. In China, the Shanghai Composite climbed 0.3% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index swung up 0.4%, continuing its recent rebound. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 ended 0.3% lower.RELATED:Nike Expected To Log First Earnings Decline In Over 4 YearsLennar Hails Post-Election Optimism As Revenue Growth AcceleratesFreeport-McMoRan Up, Copper Down On Mine RestartDow, S&P 500 Futures Rise; Here Comes The Fed, Again

J. Willard Marriott knew he didn't want to stake his future on the unpredictable livestock market. He saw enough of that from his father, who struggled financially in Marriott-Slaterville, Utah.So after graduating from the University of Utah, Willard struck out for Washington, D.C., in 1927 to set up an A&W; Root Beer franchise.He was ready for the business world. At age 13, he had farmed his own plot of land, earning $2,000 (worth $49,000 now) that season by planting produce that he determined the food markets needed.Two years later, in 1915, he rode a trainload of lambs to San Francisco to supply restaurants stocking up for the Panama-Pacific International Exposition.Likewise, he knew the Washington area from his travels doing Mormon missionary work. So Willard and his new bride, Alice, drove in their Model T Ford confidently.With them was $1,500 that he'd earned from selling woolen goods to lumber camps on commission.A Start With Root BeerAfter landing in the nation's capital, Willard borrowed another $1,500 to open a root beer outlet on 14th Street. His new partner, Hugh Colton, also invested $3,000.The return was impressive. The first year, from 1927 to 1928, sales totaled $16,000 — worth $220,000 today — and Marriott soon bought out his partner.Marriott's A&W; root beer franchise was finding sweet profit in charging 5 cents for a frosty mug filled with root beer.From this humble beginning, Marriott built a global food service and hospitality enterprise by paying attention to details and providing quality at a reasonable price.The firm lives on as Marriott International (MAR), which had 2014 sales of $14 billion and has enjoyed a 550% stock ride since 2009.Marriott (1900-85) steadily expanded his operation. He shifted his A&W; stand into selling hot food and opened other D.C.-area outlets.Next came a name change. Alice came up with Hot Shoppe, devised menu items, decorated the restaurants and kept the company books.Marriott understood the risky nature of starting a new business, with 50% failing during the first five years of operation. He felt that pain with a Washington bank that closed paying only 20 cents on the dollar to its account holders.To avert such failure on the food front, he paid attention to every detail. He hired youngsters as traffic counters at key intersections around town in order to situate new restaurants properly.Marriott's big innovation was opening the first drive-in in Washington in the summer of 1928. To advertise the new restaurant, employees passed out tickets around town for free root beer. Customers came nonstop all day long.By the 1930s, the Marriott enterprise of eight restaurants stretched all the way to Baltimore.He was on a roll, even preparing meals for Eastern Air Transport. From this venture, his firm launched its in-flight catering service for all airlines serving the D.C. area in 1937.All the while, Marriott visited every operation of Hot Shoppes and made it a point to shake hands with employees while giving the kitchen and serving areas a white-glove inspection.He insisted on cleanliness, tasty food, reasonable prices and the complete standardization of the menu for each facility.He lived by the mantra "if you take care of your employees, they will take care of your customers."He instituted bonuses for managers and gifts for longevity of service. When employees had personal tragedies, he comforted them and aided them financially."J.W. Marriott was a pioneer in employee advocacy," George Haley, director of the Center for International Industry Competitiveness and a University of New Haven marketing professor, told IBD. "Only 41% percent of companies engage in it today."With the birth of their two sons, J. Willard Jr. in 1932 and Richard in 1939, Alice stepped away from day-to-day operations but remained a force behind major corporate decisions.Meanwhile, the '30s were traumatic, as her husband was diagnosed with cancer of the lymph nodes and was expected to live only a year or less. But Marriott lived 50 more years, worked to the hilt and saw his elder son take over the reins of the business he had founded.Hard Work"J. Willard built a solid and extremely profitable business by taking to heart that no person can get very far in this world on a 40-hour week, " said executive coach Karissa Thacker in Wilmington, Del. "He kept seizing new opportunities to expand and continually experimented with his operations to perfect them. His life is a testament to learning agility."During World War II, Marriott contracted to provide meals to the Naval Communications Annex and industrial war facilities surrounding Washington. All of this activity fed company coffers that continued to grow well after the war ended in 1945. By 1952, revenue approached $20 million (worth $178 million now), generated from 58 outlets.The next year, Hot Shoppes went public at $10.25 per share. According to Lawrence Friedman's 2012 book, "Go to Market Strategy," $1,000 invested in 1953 in the firm that would turn into Marriott International would be worth well over $1 million today.Then came 1957, a watershed year for Marriott. He opened his first hotel, the 365-room Twin Bridges in Arlington, Va.By then, his company had doubled its revenue over five years to $38 million (the equivalent of $320 million now). Ten years later came a name change to Marriott Inc.The company's leadership transition from Willard to Jr. — who went by Bill — started with the launching of that first hotel.In 1972, Bill rose to chief executive and helped transform the family business into a global empire."Bill was one of the first to introduce revenue management to the hotel industry, employing analytical tools to predict consumer behavior," said Haley. "He also recognized the segmented hotel market and developed brands for each price point."Death And BeyondMarriott died age 84 at his summer home in New Hampshire. He is buried in Rockville, Md.Eight years after his death, the company split into two, Marriott International and Host Marriott, the second of which would change its name to Host Hotels & Resorts (HST) and become the nation's largest lodging real estate investment trust, with 2014 revenue of $5.4 billion.Bill relinquished the role of CEO of Marriott International to Arne Sorenson in 2011 and took on the title of executive chairman, helping oversee one of the world's largest lodging companies, with over 3,900 facilities consisting of almost 715,000 rooms in 79 countries."I'm sure it was daunting to step into the shoes of J.W., a larger-than-life business figure, but Bill kept his father's corporate culture in place and chose his own areas to expand, being one of the first hotel executives to recognize the potential overseas," said Thacker.James Berkeley of London-based Ellice Consulting lauds the company that John Willard Marriott left behind for applying "common sense more consistently and constantly than anyone else in the global lodging business. After first owning their hotels, they switched to franchising to minimize the competitive threat and improve the return on their capital. Their managers and employees are among the best in the industry and stem from their core values of taking care of its people, employing sound business practices, embracing change and pursuing excellence."

The Leisure-Lodging group outperformed Wednesday, led by Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT), which announced it is exploring strategic alternatives. Shares of the hotel chain shot up 8% to a new all-time high. The company also reported first-quarter results that topped expectations. Earnings per share climbed 3% to 65 cents a share, while revenue slid 3% to $1.42 billion. The lodging…
Stocks trimmed their losses after the Fed indicated it would wait to raise interest rates until it sees more improvement in the U.S. economy.

The central bank, which wrapped up its two-day monetary policy meeting Wednesday, said in its statement it "is reasonably confident that inflation will move back to its 2 percent objective over the medium term."

A disappointing Q1 GDP reading sent the key indexes down early in the session. Following the Fed announcement, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 were down 0.3% and 0.1% respectively, while the Dow Jones industrial average pared its loss to 0.2%. Volume was mixed, tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.

Hotels outperformed in the stock market today. Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT) gapped up and surged 8% to a new high in massive volume. The company, which operates hotels under the Sheraton, St. Regis, Westin and other brands, said it's exploring strategic alternatives, which could include a merger or sale. Starwood also reported Q1 profit and sales that beat views.

Hilton Worldwide (HLT) announced profit in line with views, while sales topped. Its full-year earnings guidance disappointed. Shares, up as much as 7% intraday, were up 2%. Among other top-rated hoteliers, Marriott International (MAR) rose 3%, Intercontinental Hotels (IHG) 1% and Hyatt Hotels (H) 2%.
GoPro (GPRO) gapped up and soared 12% after reporting Q1 EPS that doubled from last year and beat views. Shares of the June IPO are trading at nearly half their peak October level.

But Twitter (TWTR) continued its descent with a 6% loss in rapid trade. The stock tanked 18% Tuesday after its Q1 results were leaked ahead of the close. Shares are trading at their lowest level in nearly three months.
